metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: Bell OH-58 Kiowa Features and Capabilities
Later versions of Bell OH-58 Kiowa were outfitted with a glass cockpit.
The glass cockpit retained conventional instrumentation as a fallback measure.
The OH-58D introduced the Mast Mounted Sight (MMS).
The Mast Mounted Sight (MMS) is the most distinctive feature of the Kiowa family.
The Mast Mounted Sight (MMS) resembles a beach ball perched above the rotor system.
The Mast Mounted Sight (MMS) was manufactured by Ball Aerospace & Technologies.
The Mast Mounted Sight (MMS) has a gyro-stabilized platform.
The gyro-stabilized platform contains a television system (TVS).
The gyro-stabilized platform contains a thermal imaging system (TIS).
The gyro-stabilized platform contains a laser range finder/designator (LRF/D).
These features gave the OH-58D target acquisition capability in day or night.
These features gave the OH-58D target acquisition capability in limited-visibility conditions.
These features gave the OH-58D target acquisition capability in adverse weather.
These features gave the OH-58D laser designation capability in day or night.
These features gave the OH-58D laser designation capability in limited-visibility conditions.
These features gave the OH-58D laser designation capability in adverse weather.
The OH-58D has a 1553 databus.
The OH-58D was the first US Army helicopter to be fielded with a 1553 databus.
Target data from the sensors could be directly passed to precision-guided weapons.
The Mast Mounted Sight (MMS) was developed by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is located in Huntington Beach, California.

text:
Later versions were outfitted with a glass cockpit, which retained conventional instrumentation as a fallback measure.

The OH-58D introduced perhaps the most distinctive feature of the Kiowa family â€” the Mast Mounted Sight (MMS), which resembles a beach ball perched above the rotor system. The MMS by Ball Aerospace & Technologies has a gyro-stabilized platform containing a television system (TVS), a thermal imaging system (TIS), and a laser range finder/designator (LRF/D). These features gave the OH-58D the additional mission capability of target acquisition and laser designation in day or night, limited-visibility and adverse weather. In combination with the 1553 databus, the OH-58D being first US Army helicopter to be fielded with such equipment, target data from the sensors could be directly passed to precision-guided weapons.
The MMS was developed by the McDonnell Douglas Corp. in Huntington Beach, CA.
